Description: Wheel-made pottery ink-well or oil-lamp. Red slipped, with ink or soot stains around hole. Blackened or stained black, presumably through use as a oil-lamp. Red-brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Ptolemaic (?) parallel from Schedia (Abd El-Fattah 1998, 51-2, fig. 25). Two similar 'ink-wells' of the same form known from Naukratis (Fitzwilliam GR.219.1899; Cairo E33565), each with different decoration, but both of decoration types typical on Ptolemaic mould-made lamps of the period. Decoration seen on Ptolemaic mould-made lamps in same fabric as these ink-well examples (Mlynarczyk 1997, 54-7, Type G, Figs. 65-6), dated variously between late 2nd to 1st or late 3rd to 2nd century BC. Abd El-Fattah, A. 1998. Recent discoveries in Alexandria an the Chora, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 37-53. Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.079) (Phase 3)
